snippet.title: Stamp duty boost spurs first-timers in outer bayside suburbs - realestate.com.au
snippet.content:
, sold for $660,000 to first-home buyers.
FIRST-home buyers scored wins in Melbourne's southeast as stamp duty savings boosted their numbers at weekend auctions. A Parkdale unit and a Frankston house were among homes snapped up by first-time buyers, who are gaining ground in the competitive auction market, according to Advantage Property Consulting director Frank Valentic. "We have seen a definite come back from first-home buyers," Mr Valentic said. "They are out and about at a lot of auctions. Investors have ducked for cover with changes from banks and laws." Mr Valentic said a first-home buyer won the keys to the Parkdale villa unit when it sold for $660,000 under the hammer on August 5.
The Parkdale villa unit has an open-plan kitchen, meals and living area.
He said two bidders, both first-home buyers, contested the auction of with the property was declared on the market by Hocking Stuart, Mentone, at $600,000. "Villas are the jewel of the apartment market," Mr Valentic said. "They offer a bit of land and single level living." First-home buyers were also out in force further down the bay when a four-bedroom house at , was sold by O'Brien, Chelsea, for $735,000.
, sold for $735,000.
Mr Valentic said the Frankston market was going from strength to strength, having undergone a 30 per cent lift in house prices this year. "Houses are going up $10,000 a month," he said. "It's pretty hard for first-home buyers to save that each month for a deposit." Interestingly, Mr Valentic said Advantage Property Consulting was offered the property at the start of the year for $680,000, but it didn't have a buyer at the time.
Inside the four-bedroom house at 12 Cecil St, Frankston.
He said the auction result meant the house had grown $55,000 in value in six months. "The market is moving like a freight train," Mr Valentic said. "I would encourage first-home buyers to push themselves because it's not going to get any cheaper."
